turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about London Borough of Hackney.
turn.1: When was the New River formed?
turn.2: The New River was opened in 1613, diverting water from the Lea catchment to create a source of drinking water for London.
turn.3: Where is the river located today?
turn.4: The New River still passes through the borough, close to Finsbury Park and flows towards Islington.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: Another man-made feature, the Regents Canal also crosses the borough to the south of De Beauvoir Town in the west, joining the Hertford Union Canal below Victoria Park.
turn.7: What does the borough look like today?
turn.8: Much of Hackney retains an inner-city character, but in such places as Dalston large housing estates have been joined by newly developed gated communities.
turn.9: Is there any other interesting information I should know?
turn.10: In South Hackney, near Victoria Park, terraced Georgian, Victorian and Edwardian housing still survives.
turn.11: What major industries are there today?
turn.12: Light industries in the area around the River Lea employ over 3,000 people.
